unnormalised: Healthcare in India is undergoing a rapid transformation, and with it, the landscape of identifiers is becoming increasingly complex. Understanding your UHID and other related numbers is crucial. Think of it like this: your PAN card is for taxes, and these healthcare IDs are for, well, your health records!
normalised: Healthcare in India is undergoing a rapid transformation, and with it, the landscape of identifiers is becoming increasingly complex. Understanding your U-H-I-D and other related numbers is crucial. Think of it like this: your P-A-N card is for taxes, and these healthcare I-Ds are for, well, your health records!

unnormalised: For starters, let's talk about the UHID, or Unique Health Identification number. Many hospitals, especially larger ones like AIIMS Delhi and CMC Vellore, now issue a UHID to each patient. It’s usually a 12-16 digit number, something like 123456789012 or UHID-2024-ABC-0001, depending on the institution. This number helps the hospital quickly access your medical history, previous diagnoses, and treatment plans. No more flipping through dusty files; it's all digital now!
normalised: For starters, let's talk about the U-H-I-D, or Unique Health Identification number. Many hospitals, especially larger ones like A-I-I-M-S Delhi and C-M-C Vellore, now issue a U-H-I-D to each patient. It's usually a twelve to sixteen digit number, something like one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two or U-H-I-D- two thousand and twenty four-A-B-C- triple zero one, depending on the institution. This number helps the hospital quickly access your medical history, previous diagnoses, and treatment plans. No more flipping through dusty files; it's all digital now!

unnormalised: Then there's your health insurance policy number. Companies like ICICI Lombard and HDFC Ergo use these, and they’re typically alphanumeric – something like ICIL/HLTH/2023/000001. Keep this number handy, along with your policy card. You'll need it when claiming insurance at the hospital or when scheduling appointments. Some policies also have a separate claim number, which they might give you post hospitalisation.
normalised: Then there's your health insurance policy number. Companies like I-C-I-C-I Lombard and H-D-F-C Ergo use these, and they're typically alphanumeric – something like I-C-I-L slash H-L-T-H slash two thousand and twenty three slash triple zero zero zero one. Keep this number handy, along with your policy card. You'll need it when claiming insurance at the hospital or when scheduling appointments. Some policies also have a separate claim number, which they might give you post hospitalisation.

unnormalised: Ayushman Bharat, the government's flagship health scheme, also uses identifiers. For those eligible, there’s an Ayushman Bharat card number, which can look like AB-XXXX-YYYY-ZZZZ. This card gives access to free or subsidized medical treatment at empanelled hospitals. Also, it is often linked to your Aadhaar number, making it easier to identify beneficiaries. Remember to carry your Ayushman Bharat card during hospital visits.

Also, it is often linked to your Aadhaar number, making it easier to identify beneficiaries. Remember to carry your Ayushman Bharat card during hospital visits.

unnormalised: Don't forget about the Employee State Insurance (ESI) number. This is relevant if you’re employed in a company covered under the ESI scheme. Your ESI number, something like 12-345678-90-1234, is used to access medical benefits at ESI hospitals and dispensaries. Make sure your employer provides you with this number when you join.
normalised: Don't forget about the Employee State Insurance (E-S-I) number. This is relevant if you're employed in a company covered under the E-S-I scheme. Your E-S-I number, something like one two-three four five six seven eight-nine zero-one two three four, is used to access medical benefits at E-S-I hospitals and dispensaries. Make sure your employer provides you with this number when you join.

unnormalised: In short, keep all these healthcare and insurance IDs safe and easily accessible. Whether it's a UHID from a private hospital, an Ayushman Bharat card number, or an ESI number, they are essential for navigating India’s growing healthcare system. Save them in your phone, write them down, but just remember where they are!
